Fields.DialogueText: Provence, the ship's moving on its own. What are you doing?
*ALARM*
What does it look like I'm doing?
I have no idea, but you'd better stop. We have company.
Of course, but that's why I'm moving the ship in the first place.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think we're in danger?
Is this another "art" thing?
Whatever it is, you can stop now.

Fields.DialogueText: Negative, Capitaine.
Oui. Why do you look so shocked?
I absolutely cannot stop!
I am trying to set up the perfect composition. I need every ship to be in the right place. And as you cannot trust Morganas to behave...
I am moving the ship myself!
We need to deal with the enemy fleet before you can prepare your art.
But--
No buts about this one, Provence. Turn this ship around.
... Yes, Capitaine.
Don't look so glum. We've still got a fight ahead of us.
Oui. Let's give them what we've got. ... And try to arrange them nicely, Capitaine?
I'll do my best.
@BATTLE
@ALARM
Capitaine! May I move the ship this time?
No, Provence.
I know you want to make your perfect composition, but that can wait.
Pas de tout! Not at all.
If I am inspired to do something and cannot do it, then what will I become? Miserable!

Fields.MenuText: No, but the Morganas are too dangerous.
No, but I can't put our crew in danger.
The mission comes first.

Fields.DialogueText: Pas de tout. I can handle them!
My assistants are capable!
But... But... Capitaine, je ne veux pas--
I want you to be happy, but not if it means endangering the rest of the crew.
We stand and fight, and no moving the ship unless it's necessary. Understood?
Oui, Capitaine.
*BOOM*
Come on! Let's go!
@BATTLE
Do you want your lover to be miserable?
I'd rather you be sad and alive.
Hey, Provence. About the other day--
Are you still mad at me, Capitaine?
What? No!
You gave me the stare of disapprobation. My heart sank to my knees.
This is about your perfect art piece. You need to make it, right?
It's all I can think about!

Fields.MenuText: I can't justify spending Fleet resources on your art, but...
You're never going to get Morganas to do what you want to do, but-
If you want to set up a composition, why don't you--

Fields.DialogueText: Please do not give me advice, Capitaine! I know my own art better than anyone.
If I can time things correctly, maybe I can!
Capitaine, I assure you, I don't want to cause any trouble. Just--
Let me finish.
I'm going to ask the INPF if we can do some training exercises. And once you're done, you can stage all the shipwrecks you like.
How would that work, exactly?
Still figuring it out. But there's less risk of real danger--
*ALARM*
Speak of the devil and she will appear.
Indeed. So, are we agreed?
You've had worse plans, Capitaine. I'll consider it.
Good. Let's go get those Morganas!
@BATTLE
I wasn't ever mad at you.
I thought you would ask us to part forever!
That's not going to happen. I'm your captain and you're my Belle.
No room to spare for me, dear?
What! Capitaine, I adore you...
Relax, Provence, I'm joking.
Is that orders from the Neutrality Fleet, Capitaine?
It is. I think it's about your training exercise.
Ah! I can't look - what does it say?
... Oh dear.
*ALARM*
No! Curse you, witches, you'll get yours for this!
Dramatic, aren't you?
I cannot help it. The suspense is killing me!
@BATTLE
So? What did the letter say?
... I'm afraid the Fleet said they can't spare any ships, awake or no.
That's terrible! How will I ever finish my composition?

Fields.MenuText: There's always the power of imagination.
Maybe you can move some Morgana wrecks around?
Well, you could always tip yourself over for a minute...

Fields.DialogueText: Putain de bordel de merde, Capitaine. You know that's impractical.
We could try, but I'm not a tugboat.
If I could get this painting right with only my imagination, believe me, it would be finished by now!
Hmmm... I know! Perhaps my sisters could help.
I'll write to them. There's strength in numbers, isn't there? Perhaps the fleet will listen to all three of us.
It's worth a try. Good luck!
Merci, Capitaine.
Provence? Why are you lying on the floor?
It's hopeless, Capitaine. Everything is calamity and despair.
We've got clear seas and clear skies. And we've got each other, don't we?
What we don't have is a training exercise. My sisters can't be spared either.
How will I ever arrange my perfect composition now?

Fields.MenuText: The Fleet did tell you you weren't roping anyone else into this.
I'm sorry, Provence. Is there anything I can do?
Can't you just use your imagination?

Fields.DialogueText: And I was a fool for not listening, but I thought there'd be strength in numbers.
No! No. There is nothing anyone can do for me now.
Capitaine, you wound me! If I could do this from memory, I would have been finished by now.
Alas, I have no choice but to sink into dark despair. Maybe even another Black Period. Who can say?
Get a hold of yourself! Things will be fine in the morning, all right?
... Where'd she go?
*ALARM*
Damn! Everyone to battle stations.
I've got you. You're safe. You're going to be fine.
And someone find Provence!
@BATTLE
Capitaine, I have a status report.
At ease. Let's hear it.
We found Provence. She was in the engine room. Alive, unharmed, just sulking.

Fields.MenuText: Thank God.

Fields.DialogueText: I gave her a pen and some paper, and she seems happier.
I'll go find her. Good work, Kwan.
Just doin' my job, Capitaine.
La, la, la, la...
There you are!
Capitaine!
That looks more technical than your usual drawings.  Does that mean you feel better?
Somewhat. Thank you for asking.
Can I see it? Or will I have to wait until it's done?
You will have to wait until it is done. Just like everyone else.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I'm glad you're feeling better.
You won't show little old me?
Next time, can you skip the sulking and just do this?

Fields.DialogueText: Merci. I'm also glad.
No, Capitaine. I'm... sorting through some things right now. Feelings I can't bear.
It may sound strange to you, but... I do not enjoy having feelings that are too large.
Can you skip crying when you are sad, or laughing when you are happy?
They just... are. They wash over me like waves. I can't control them.
Part of being an adult is learning to control your feelings.
I have been an adult for the entirety of my existence, Capitaine.
That's not what I--
*ALARM*
Dammit!
No time to lose, Capitaine. I'll meet you on the deck.
@BATTLE
Maybe I could help you bear them.
Non. They're too large for anyone. I have to shrink them into art before I can share them.

Fields.MenuText: Good work.
Good grief.

Fields.DialogueText: This shore leave couldn’t have come at a better time.
The harbor’s never looked so welcome, don’t you think?
Hm? I honestly wasn’t paying attention…
Still working on those sketches?
Less like sketches and more like blueprints, Capitaine.
I’ve been talking to Engineer Kwan, and she’s been helping me make sure it will hold together…

Fields.MenuText: I’m getting sick of all the hush-hush. What are you planning?
Are you going to build whatever-this-is when we get to port?
Will I see your buildings in Paris someday?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe! We’ll have to see if it's a good design. But I have faith.
Can’t I have a little privacy, Capitaine? A lady must have her mystery.
Maybe! But this isn’t a building…
Well, I look forward to seeing it, whatever it is.
Thank you, Capitain. I hope it’s worth the wait!
*ALARM*
Bordel de merde! Are you serious?
If Morganas are attacking the port, it’s our duty to help with the defense.
Of course, but they made me draw a line crooked.
If we were not already at war…
Well, we are, so let’s finish this!
@BATTLE
Ignoring me, I see? Art really is your true love.
You know where you can shove that one, Capitaine.
Come on, mates - let’s take care of these stragglers!
@BATTLE
What’s all this wood for, Kwan? There’s enough to build a house!
Miss Provence said I’m not supposed to talk about it. It’s a surprise.
Capitain! It’s coming along nicely, don’t you think?
What is? Your super-secret project?
… Should we tell the Capitaine, Miss Provence?
It’s under way, so I guess there’s no harm in it.
We’re building a toy boat!
What?
If you want to stage a shipwreck, what better way is there than to wreck an actual ship?
Exactement!
My plan is to build a very small false ship and sink it during the training exercise.
With forced perspective and some clever framing, we can get the exact right composition.

Fields.MenuText: Seems like a lot of work for a painting.
How are you going to get this thing out to sea?
How much like a real ship is she?

Fields.DialogueText: No more than the old masters did. It’s harder to study anatomy when you can’t look at a body.
Leave it to me, Capitaine! I can tow her.
As close as we can get her! We’ve even mocked up an engine block.
Well, this seems like an interesting project.
As long as Command will give us the green light, I’m all right with it.
Thank you, Capitaine! I promise I won’t get in the way!
Hard to see how this won’t. But, if it makes you happy…
Capitaine, believe me - it very much will.
Wow, I can’t believe you got the Toy Boat finished so quickly.
She’s only a model.
Well, yes, but she’s still so detailed! I can see every rivet on the hull.
Engineer Kwan helped me with the mechanical side of things. The Toy Boat wouldn’t look nearly as good if she hadn’t been there.

Fields.MenuText: She deserves a promotion.
You both went into the wrong career, didn’t you?
I think you could have made it work.

Fields.DialogueText: I wonder what our commanders will say to that - but let them talk!
If I can help it, they won't say much.
I am a Belle, Capitaine. We don't get much choice.
Suppose not...
I’d have wasted a lot more wood. So many prototypes…
... Can we have a word in private?
What’s wrong?
*ALARM*
Nothing important. Let's defend the port.
Affirmative. All hands on deck!
@BATTLE
I believe in you, dear.
Well, shore leave is over.
Finally!
... Command did sign off on that quote-unquote training exercise, right?

Fields.MenuText: What would you do if I said "no?"
I’ve got the letter right here.
I don’t know. Haven’t opened the letter yet.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I’d be absolutely stricken. There’s no guarantee what would happen.
I might go completely insane and paint the entire ship orange. Or worse--
Oh! What does it say?
Please, Capitaine, the suspense is killing me!
Capitaine! You hold my heart in your hands, and you toy with it so cruelly?
Oh, Provence. I was getting to it...
Let’s see here…
Mon dieu, I can’t look….
They approved it, no questions asked.
What!?
Frankly, I think they’re happy you don’t want to throw yourself into danger for a change.
Capitaine, this is…
I could kiss you right now!
Hey, hey, we're still on duty! We've got to act professional.
Sorry, Capitaine! I promise, you won’t regret this--
*ALARM*
Let’s see how well you can fight while towing that thing.
I can assure you we’ll be up to the task!
@BATTLE
Provence, you wanted to talk about something?
Oh, yes, Capitain….
What’s the matter?
Nothing is wrong. It was just… a thought. An unpleasant one.
You’re prone to those, aren’t you?
The nerve!
All I'm saying is that you have a morbid streak.
A little, but...
When we were building the toy boat, I remembered.
Isn’t there a Belle that didn't start her life as a ship?
How do you figure? I haven’t seen any Belles running around without a boat.
She’s American. USS… Re-something.
Oh, Recruit? Yes, she was a wooden ship before the Morganas showed up. Did the Toy Boat remind you of her?
You know, no one knows how Belles wake up…

Fields.MenuText: Are you’re scared you’ve made a Belle?
I don’t think you can make a Belle on purpose, dear.
If you did, wouldn't she have shown up by now?

Fields.DialogueText: Something like that, yes.
Well, I didn't mean to make one.
Who can say? No one knows anything about how we work.
But it's clear that, if we did accidentally create a Belle...
... If we did, then we'll cross that bridge when we get to it. For now--
*ALARM*
Son of a motherless goat.
For now, let's take care of business!
@BATTLE
... Does that mean I have a "daughter" ship, Capitaine?
Provence, are you *painting* the Toy Boat?
Yes, Capitaine. Is there a problem?
Not at all. I just thought you were going to sink it before you could do anything with it.
Well, she deserves to be pretty, doesn't she?

Fields.MenuText: Do you really think she'll turn into a Belle?
It's a lot of work to put into something so temporary.
You really love that thing, don't you?

Fields.DialogueText: Do not call her a thing!
All art is ephemeral, Capitain.
I don't know. I don't know what I think. Or what I want.
Thank you. I worked really hard.
Do you see these white floral patterns? They're based on corded quilts from Marseilles.
Well, you did a great job.
And here, these sunflowers - they're inspired by Van Gogh.
She looks amazing.
Yes. I almost wish I didn't have to scuttle her.
*ALARM*
Let's make sure they don't scuttle you.
Agreed, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
Are we ready?
Aye, Miss. On three - HEAVE!
Ah, Capitaine! You're just in time for the Toy Boat's maiden voyage.
Are you going to sink her now?
No. We're trying to make sure that she'll float first.
Seems like a bit of a waste.
I'd like to have some bodies in the water, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: You're too cute to be this morbid.
I guess if you're going for realism...
You're not going to endanger the crew, are you!?

Fields.DialogueText: Is it not possible for me to be both?
Exactly. A large shipwreck would have many survivors...
Of course not! We're going to be right there.
We will send lifeboats as soon as I have positions sketched out.
... But that means we need to make sure the Toy Boat won't sink, right?
Exactly. Oh, here she goes--
*SPLASH*
We did it! She's on the move!
The hidden oars work like a dream.
Thank you, Engineer Kwan. I couldn't have done this without your help.
*ALARM*
Bring her back in.  We've got company!
@BATTLE
I suppose...
We got more lavender tea while we were docked. Would you like some?
Of course. You're too kind to me.
Mmm... this is the good stuff.
Something on your mind?
Ah, mon chou, you know me too well.
Ahh... I'll confess. It's the Toy Boat.
What about her?
... Is it wrong that I wanted her to wake up, Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: Yes. You can't create life on a whim.
No. You take great pride in your work.
That's between you and God.

Fields.DialogueText: It wasn't just that. Though that was part of it.
Yet humans do it every day, for much worse reasons.
Do you think there's any room for God here?
... Capitaine, I... I'd make a terrible mother, but...
... I've always wanted to create something that would come to life. A painting you could walk into. A portrait that could speak.
... And you thought by making a Belle... you'd make that dream come true.
I thought you were terrified she'd wake.
I did, yes. But there's more to it than that.
*ALARM*
Even if you won't, best not to think on it now. Let's go.
Right behind you.
@BATTLE
There was a part of me that... wanted to give you a child.
What?
I know. I *know.* I can barely act like an adult myself.
But if you wanted a family someday, I can't... I don't know if I can give you that, because I'm a Belle. And...
... Listen, Provence...
I love you because you're you. It doesn't matter what you can or can't give me.
Will you still say that when the war's over?

Fields.MenuText: Of course. I love you.
I don't know.
I just want you to be happy.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, this is it. Are you ready to pick the spot for your painting?
Ready as I'll ever be.
You don't sound too happy about it.
... I know you spent some capital on this, Capitaine, but... surely the Fleet has more important things for us to do?
Most likely. But there's no helping that now.
Zut. Always ready to tell the hard truths, aren't you, Capitaine?
... I'm worried about the Toy Boat. I don't know if sinking her is the right call.
Well, maybe you can just float her out and arrange your composition around her?
Maybe. ... I keep thinking, if she really was my daughter...
*ALARM*
... Let's paint the seas with these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Would I be so quick to send her to her doom?

Fields.MenuText: Humans do it all the time.
What if she isn't alive?
I think you're overthinking this.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course I am! Would you not overthink destroying your own child?!
Yes, but... not with so much ill intent.
I wish I had your optimism, Capitaine.
Hoist away! Lower her in three... two...
She's just about ready, Miss.
Are you still going aboard?
Of course. Someone's gotta have boots on the ground.
Setting sail, eh, Provence?
Oui, Capitaine. We're boarding the crew now.

Fields.MenuText: Must be exciting.
Are you nervous?
Don't lose hope. You're almost there.

Fields.DialogueText: It's not hope I have a problem with.
Of course I am nervous. There is a lot riding on this.
The butterflies in my stomach are having a ball, Capitaine.
All right, we're heading out. Wish me luck?
There's only a few left. Let's give them what for!
@BATTLE
Ah, wishing someone luck can be bad luck!
How's that supposed to work?
Don't ask me!
Well, good luck, Provence. I hope you get the painting you need.
Turn sixteen degrees starboard! No, no - seventeen degrees.
Steady... steady...
Trying to make your perfect composition, Provence?
Yes. I have to get everything just right.
Kwan, status report?
Holding steady, Miss.
Good. Just keep the Toy Boat where I want you to--
What's that on the horizon?
It looks like... an armada.
Make radio contact. See if we can get them talking.
Negative, Capitaine. It looks like--
Oh, this is bad. This is very bad.
What's wrong?
Can't you feel it? The wave of despair--
*THUNDER*

Fields.MenuText: A whole armada of Morganas!?
This doesn't look good...
Damn your perfect painting. We have to run.

Fields.DialogueText: I've never seen this many out here.
You can say that again, Capitaine. Especially with the oncoming storm--
I couldn't agree more, Capitaine.
Huh?
We need to get the crew back aboard.
Affirmative, Capitaine. And the Toy Boat--
The boat's not a priority. Our people are.
But--
We're outnumbered and outgunned. Our objective is to get out of here, understand?
...Oui, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
I know you love the Toy Boat, but we've got a duty to the crew.
*THUNDER*
There's too many of them, Capitaine!
We have to get out of here. Where's your toy boat?
We've lost sight of her, Capitaine.
Damn it.
She has to be around here somewhere. Circle around.
I'm so sorry. This is all my fault, Capitaine--

Fields.MenuText: Keep sharp, Provence. We'll get through this together.
Doesn't matter whose fault it is now.
Yes, it is. But that doesn't matter.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Capitaine.
It does matter.  I put my assistants into danger. And Engineer Kwan--
I was afraid you'd say that.
We need to focus on getting the crew back safely.
Let's cut through these Morganas and bring back our crew!
Roger that, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, I see the boat!
Where? Where is she?
Six o'clock. Past all the Morganas.
Of course she is.
Wait - is she *moving?*
What?
Capitaine, I can feel her moving. Like a Belle. We have to save her.

Fields.MenuText: The crew's lives come first.
If she's really a Belle, we've got to protect her.
We need to wipe out the Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: I hoped you'd say that, Capitaine. Thank you.
Of course, Capitaine. If anything happens to Engineer Kwan because of me--!
Feeling bloodthirsty, Capitaine? I am too.
Before anything else, we need to rendezvous with the Toy Boat and get the crew off. Then if we can, we try to retrieve her.
Sink as many of these Morganas as possible, but this is a rescue mission, not a revenge. Understand?
Yes, Capitaine.
*THUNDER*
She's coming this way!
Pilot, steer a course towards the Toy Boat!
@BATTLE
We're closing in, Capitaine!
The Morganas keep coming. We don't have much time!
Provence--
We'll get you off of there, I promise!
Get everyone off the Toy Boat! We don't leave anyone behind!
*THUNDER*
Capitaine, the Morgs are surrounding us!

Fields.MenuText: Steady.... don't do anything rash.
Stay focused. We get the crew, we get out of here.
Let 'em come. We can handle them.

Fields.DialogueText: We're trying our best, Capitaine, but--
We're holding position, Capitaine, but--
We might keep our cool, but--
The Toy Boat can't!
She's sailing straight into the middle of the Morgana storm. We have to go after her!
Have the crew gotten to safety?
Engineer Kwan is still aboard.
She didn't want to leave anyone else behind. We can't let her sacrifice herself for nothing!
Cut through the rest of the Morganas. We'll do our best to save her.
@BATTLE
Any sign of Engineer Kwan?
Not yet. I will keep looking.
We may have to turn back.
I will not give up hope!

Fields.MenuText: There's a swarm of Morganas out there.
The needs of the many might outweigh--
I don't want to give up either, but--

Fields.DialogueText: But what? But what!? With all due respect--
Please do not give up hope, Capitaine--
And we know how to deal with Morganas, don't we?
Engineer Kwan sighted, sir!
Copy that. Moving in.
Capitaine! I'm trapped under this rubble-
We'll get you out of there. Hang on!
I'm so sorry--
Sorry won't get me out of here! If you push on that beam there, you'll have more leverage--
Yes! You're almost free. Just a little more--
We're going to have to fight our way out. Everyone brace yourselves!
Ah! I'm free! Throw me a line!
Aye-aye, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
*THUNDER*
Is everyone aboard?
Everyone's present and accounted for. Except--
The Toy Boat...
She's starting to fall apart. We can't bring her back aboard and get out safely.
I know, but--

Fields.MenuText: Do you want to risk your crew's lives for this?
We can't do this. I'm sorry, Provence.
It's us or it, Provence.

Fields.DialogueText: ... No need for apologies, Capitaine. We do what we must.
... Non. I understand, Capitaine.
That's a harsh way to look at it. But I understand.
... Say your goodbyes and get ready to run.
Oui, Capitaine. I understand.
Let's go! Push the engines! Give it everything we've got!
Aye-aye, Capitaine. ... What in the name of--
The Toy Boat's... moving? Like it's being steered.
It's coming around the back to protect us from the Morganas!
Well, that's great news for us.  Full steam ahead.
... Adieu, my masterpiece. Adieu.
@BATTLE
Thank God we survived.
... It was a close call, Capitain. We were lucky to get out of there.
You can say that again.
... I'm sorry about the Toy Boat.
It is, as they say, the way of all flesh.

Fields.MenuText: I know you loved her.
If you need anything, I'm here.
... We're at war. You're going to lose people.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, Capitain. Trust me, I have seen good soldiers die.
Thank you, Capitaine, but what I need is to stay busy.
Of course I did. She was a wonderful creation.
If she had woken up, she would have been our daughter. ... But it doesn't matter now.
... At this point, we all have. It's best to carry on.
Are you sure, Provence?
Keep moving forward?
Exactly, Capitaine.
I'll do what I can. And thank you. It means the world to me that you... well...
I couldn't help you keep her safe. The least I can do is help you grieve.
*sniff*
*ALARM*
Well, here comes another way to keep busy.
*sniff* ... Sometimes the universe is kind after all.
@BATTLE
I... I... If I hold still, I'll drown. I need you to help me keep my head above water.
Do you need a hug?
Y-yes, Capitaine. Yes, I do.
Here. I've got you.
*sniff... sniff...*
*sob*
Painting again, Provence?
Oui, mon chou.
Glad to see you're feeling a little better.
As I said, I have to keep busy.
I'm assuming I can't see the painting?
You know me too well, Capitaine. Not until it's done.

Fields.MenuText: Is this your perfect composition, then?
This looks like a portrait.
You're very private about your art.

Fields.DialogueText: It is how I understand the world, Capitaine. Of course I am private about it.
Non. I have decided... to put that aside, for now.
Very astute, Capitaine.
It will not be a perfect composition, but... I hope it is a good one.
My art is a window into my soul. It is imperfect, because I am imperfect.
It was a noble idea, but... I put everyone in danger trying to achieve perfection.
Well, I like all the art you make. "Perfect" or no.
But if I share it with you, it is a revelation.
Thank you, Capitaine.
*ALARM*
Here we go again! Are you ready for a fight?
Perfectly ready, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
... You make me want to make art.
That's the highest compliment you could ever give me.
It's funny. When you're around... I feel calm and safe. You make me feel warm and inspired.
I'm unveiling the painting, Capitaine. Would you like to see?
Of course! What've you got for me?
Guess, Capitaine!
Is it...

Fields.MenuText: A portrait of me?
A portrait of Engineer Kwan?
A self-portrait?

Fields.DialogueText: Mais non, Capitaine! Though she does bear a resemblance...
Non. But now that you mention it, maybe I should have her sit for a portrait...
Non, but now that you mention it, that's not such a bad idea...
So who is it?
I decided to paint a portrait of the Toy Boat as if she were a Belle, Capitaine.
Incredible. You got so many fine details...
She looks a little like you.
Another day, another wandering Morgana.
Let's drive her off quickly, Capitaine! I have something important to show you.
@BATTLE
In a sense, you could say she was our daughter ship.
So I painted her as such. What do you think?
I think...
Maybe someday you will design your own daughter ship.
Maybe. I know I would need help. I'm an artist, not an engineer.
Well, that's what friends are for.
And I know she'll be just as capable as her mother.
Draw me like one of your ukiyo-e girls?
Oh, hush. I told you that was the only book I could find!
But she also bears a resemblance to you!
Oui. And she also looks like you, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: ... she has your eyes.
... she has my nose.
... she looks beautiful.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, I have a whole sketchbook page dedicated to your nose from different angles.
Never change, Provence.
You flatter me, mon chou.
I'm telling the truth. They look so bright...
Thank you. I worked very hard to make her that way.
You have Engineer Kwan, you have your sisters...
And most of all, I have you.
Always. If you do have a daughter ship, she'll be ours. Both of ours.
